title: Confused...Need an answer. Unfair.
body:
Yesterday I got an email about my other account: 123blooddrunk from riot stating I was suspended for 2 weeks for violating terms of use. I was playing fine all day the night before and nothing was going on. I did not receive a warning, a chat log, a report card or anything. I later posted on the boards stating the issue and got a response from a red saying that "If the message was vague it is because they assume you know what you did and if you want more details you have to contact support." 

I contacted support and got a message back saying I was suspended for 2 weeks because I was using foul language and they would direct my ticket to a behavior specialist so they can provide me with more information. I never got a warning about my behavior or anything just went straight to a 2 week suspension. I did not get the standard 10 game chat ban>25 game chat ban>2 week suspension. I also was not provided with any logs or report cards in the email or even upon logging in (can't even log in).

The thing is I was saying bad words because I got frustrated with myself, but they were appearing as asterisks on my screen so I don't understand why I was suspended for that because it isn't fair. I found out that there is a language filter toggle so it is possible to see the words, but I did not know this and was suspended because of it. First of all I never got a warning so I don't deserve a 2 week suspension and third of all why even have a language filter toggle if you can be suspended/banned for saying bad words? 

Completely unfair I deserve an answer.

So you didn't understand what is acceptable and unacceptable even though you've already been through this 3 times on your other account? 

The escalation system is not a defined set of steps that a player goes through. What it means is the system will punish more strictly players who are repeat offenders. Your OTHER account was banned after manual review, and you must contact player support for more information.

You do have a point, but I didn't know people could see my bad words. Regardless if it happened on another account they are treated as separate entities so the argument that the punishments are combined is invalid, unfair, and unjust. I will not stand for this.

I never said your punishments were combined. What I did say is that the escalation system is not something you are guaranteed to hit every level on before a perma-ban. It isn't designed to protect repeat offenders, it is designed to punish repeat offenders for severely. Severe enough offenses can even skip directly to perma-ban without a warning. But, your punishment happened completely independent of this system by manual review. You need to contact player support regarding your punishment.

I appreciate your insight and advice and I can assure you that I have sent a ticket in and I am now passing the 24 hour mark waiting for a response. I can also assure you that the type of behavior was no different than when I got restricted on this account compared to my other one, yet this one got warnings and the other one didn't. 

Just trying to see the understand the exact rules, guidelines, and terms of use.
You understand the goal is to get you to stop that behavior right? Not just have you do it over and over slowly going through the system over and over on new accounts.

Let me tell you a little secret about information technology. Riot is able to identify something called an IP address, (and that doesn't stand for influence points), this is essentially your address when it comes to your Internet access. Even if you are using a different account, they can tell that you are accessing their server from the same Internet service provider. They can tell that you are the same person. I don't know if they use this information when determining how harshly to drop the hammer on someone, but I know they can. 

The solution remains that you are not changing your behavior and you are expecting a different result.

Furthermore, Riot can tell different players apart by play patterns, mouse movements, etc. with pretty solid reliability.  Would that be 100% conclusive?  No.  But would I want them to protect new players by giving a harsher punishment scale to those it suspected of being previously banned players?  Heck yeah.

Riot doesn't need proof.  It's their game.  They can ban whoever they want for whatever reason they want.   If someone from an IP address gets banned, and Riot has good reason to suspect that the same player is playing another account, I really really want them to treat that new player more harshly than they would any other new player.  

Most new players have a really crappy time dealing with players in your situation.  Why should Riot want 100% proof to help deal with that?  

Frankly, I think the game would be a lot more fun if Riot took away a few of the punishment tiers between chat restriction and account ban, and escalated more quickly on everyone.  The least they could do is escalate more quickly on probably previously banned players.

Interesting point, but when a company is this large they can't just "do whatever they want because its their game" they have to treat everyone the same. There are laws for that. 

Also to expand on your point about more harsh punishments, I think the problem would be resolved if they actually removed every punishment. This is a good example. 

http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1028740/Accident-free-zone-The-German-town-scrapped-traffic-lights-road-signs.html

Laws in most jurisdictions state that certain protected classes of people must be treated the same, but say nothing about individuals.  Riot is certainly within their rights to ban whatever individual players they want for whatever reasons they want (excepting for a few protected classes like gender, race, etc.).  Location--especially specific IP address is not a protected class, and if they wanted to turn off entire IP blocks if one player broke the rules once within them, they would be entirely within their rights.

Riot is able to structure their punishment tiers however they wish, and while to some players they seem too rigid, to others they seem too lax.  For the most part I'm quite happy with their behavior team.  

The solution of removing punishments entirely... is more than a bit unsuited for free online multiplayer games.  I remember what LoL was like 4 years ago, and I am very glad the community has improved since then, or I'd probably have quit myself.
